subject: NET-387 portolan command line asks for --vnet_id but really wants --vnet-id NET-390 portolan should support intra-DC cross vnet routing TRITON-498 SVP packets with bad CRCs will crash portolan Reviewed by: Dan McDonald <danmcd@joyent.com> Approved by:
commitMessage:
NET-387 portolan command line asks for --vnet_id but really wants --vnet-id
NET-390 portolan should support intra-DC cross vnet routing
TRITON-498 SVP packets with bad CRCs will crash portolan
Reviewed by: Dan McDonald <danmcd@joyent.com>
Approved by:

Dammit.  If we introduce SVP_LOG_ROUTE, we will have to version something or else we'll cause varpd to panic.  See line 157 of libvarpd_svc_shootdown.c (svp_shootdown_logr_shoot()).
You can steal what's in illumos-joyent currently if you need.

Should a commit to master be using a commit in a !master branch?
Yes.  I've added a -1 (from myself) to this review.  I need to push portolan-moray first, get the changeset id from that, and then push this changeset.
Does this need to be done?
Does this also need to get done?
We should discuss this in VPC.  I think the intent for now is to leave out the JSON backend support for vnetroutes.  If so then I should probably remove all of my changes in this file.
Yeah, Moray-only seems prudent at this stage.
My JS knowledge is limited, but in C I'd discourage using !<ptr>.

Agreed... in C... but since we are dynamically typed if routes is 0,false,null,undefined,"" then !routes would be true. I want to catch all of that possible garbage, and return not found in the event that it is there.  

The other piece to this is that while portolan_moray.vnetRouteLookup() should return an array (even [] on no results), I don't want to depend on that.  And calling `length` on undefined will throw a Reference or Type Error, but in this case !routes will catch that since JS is short-circuit evaluated just like C.
Clearly JS is different enough.  Thank you.
The existing vl2 stuff doesn't mod_client.connect() locally like you do here.  Is this infrastructure here to make the cross-DC that much easier in the future?
Yes this is for cross DC expansion.  See the comment above about "When we implement cross-DC fabrics".
In types.js, you set the version to 2.  If I have a version 1 varpd, will it cause this log to trigger a lot?

Yes.  It's kind of a trade off I suppose.  In general, I'm a bit liberal with the logging. 

From my view I'd prefer to have extra logging that will point directly to why my fabrics deployment isn't working as expected, but I could probably be convinced otherwise.
If you've not upgraded all of your CNs to SVP v2, you will get a lot of these from any old CN packets.

We're committing to v2?  That's fine, but see my other comment about v1s showing up.

Put another way:   are you expecting a SVP client who knows about Routing to send EVERYTHING v2?  Or just the new stuff?

I think it would be fairly resource intensive and deliver low reward to make every operation version aware.  In a perfect world the SVP protocol (as well as varpd and portolan) would have been designed from the ground up to be per operation version aware.

Right now we just have a list of supported operations per version, and ability to negotiate(downgrade) for a given call.  Also note that per the copyright we haven't needed to bump the version in 4 years.

See what I did in libvarpd_svp.  I now send a ping and will honor the version in its response.  You match v2 with v2, so that's what the connection will stick with.  (Note also that my code should be mismatched-portolan-version aware in Tritons with more than one portolan running.)
If a shootdown shows up with route subfields, how do you check for that?

Shootdown messages aren't actually implemented (I know, right!  What else have they lied to me about). This line is a carry over from other code (which lays a ground work for shootdowns) for consistency.  

Currently we only "shootdown" (remove) routes via logs, which are inserted by NAPI, and varpd polls for every so often.
As with other TODOs, how critical are these?
These are notes that I added for existing functionality that isn't tested.
Didn't get an answer to: "Does this need to be done?"

It's not necessary for the first push.  We have the ability to remove vnetroutes, but this is a place holder for adding the ability to do so via the command line.  Currently the portolan command doesn't support ANY removals (vl2, vl3, etc).

I added it, and it was somewhat inaccurate, and really only intended as notes for me while I was learning the code.
